name: E. Anna and the Valentine's Day Gift
statement:
Sasha gave Anna a list a of n integers for Valentine’s Day. Anna doesn’t
need this list, so she suggests destroying it by playing a game.Players
take turns. Sasha is a gentleman, so he gives Anna the right to make the
first move. On her turn, choose an element a_i from the list and the
sequence of its digits. For example, if Anna chose the element with a
value of 42, it would become 24; if Anna chose the element with a value
of 1580, it would become 851. Note that leading zeros are removed. After
such a turn, the number of elements in the list does not change. On his
turn, extract elements a_i and a_j (i
ne j) from the list, them in any order and insert the result back into
the list. For example, if Sasha chose the elements equal to 2007 and 19,
he would remove these two elements from the list and add the integer
200719 or 192007. After such a turn, the number of elements in the list
decreases by 1.Players can’t skip turns. The game ends when Sasha can’t
make a move, i.e. Anna’s move there is one number left in the list. If
this integer is 10^m (i.e.,
ge 10^m), Sasha wins. Otherwise, Anna wins.It can be shown that the game
will always end. Determine who will win if both players play optimally.
